qas.question: When did the last country to adopt the Gregorian calendar start using it?
At what date did the first country start using the new calendar?
How which calendar did some countries notate the date?
Who said that English writers usually used both dates on writings?
What difference in dating caused the use of double-dating documents?

plausible_answers.text: the first countries adopted the Gregorian calendar

qas.question: What happened in the fifteenth century that made it necessary to give dates using both calendars?

plausible_answers.text: the last European country adopted it

qas.question: What happened in the nineteenth century the Gregorian calendar that made it necessary to give dates using both calendars?

plausible_answers.text: some countries already beginning their numbered year on 1 January

qas.question: Why was it not necessary to use the dual year when giving two dates?

plausible_answers.text: because of the different beginnings of the year in various countries

qas.question: Why did the year sometimes have to be double dated after 1582?

plausible_answers.text: immediately after 1582 English letter writers "customarily" used "two dates" on their letters, one OS and one NS

context: During the period between <a1_0>1582<a1_0/>, when <b5_0>the first countries adopted the Gregorian calendar<b5_0/>, and <a0_0>1923<a0_0/>, when <b6_0>the last European country adopted it<b6_0/>, it was often necessary to indicate the date of some event <a2_0>in both<a2_0/> the Julian calendar and in the Gregorian calendar, for example, "10/21 February 1750/51", where the dual year accounts for <b7_0>some countries already beginning their numbered year on 1 January<b7_0/> while others were still using some other date. Even before 1582, the year sometimes had to be double dated <b8_0>because of the <a4_0>different beginnings of the year<a4_0/> in various countries<b8_0/>. <a3_0>Woolley<a3_0/>, writing in his biography of John Dee (1527–1608/9), notes that <b9_0>immediately after 1582 English letter writers "customarily" used "two dates" on their letters, one OS and one NS<b9_0/>.
